# Listen üéß

## Podcasts

[The Empire](https://open.spotify.com/show/0sBh58hSTReUQiK4axYUVx) podcast covers the British Empire, Roman Empire, Ashoka's Empire, etc., and their impact on India and Asia.
The episodes are phenomenal, detailed, and cover aspects of history that I had no clue about!
I've written about [Warren Hastings](https://blog.harsh17.in/warren-hastings/) and [Robert Clive](https://blog.harsh17.in/battle-of-palassey/) based on what I listened to here.
I'd recommend the first seven episodes in a row about the [East India Company](https://open.spotify.com/episode/5PzZJyc4xhV578ISnLC8dc?si=234e3d2169d44890), [1857 rebellion](https://open.spotify.com/episode/3Ezg2VX3Ou96BVsK0aQl7y?si=9c7b942df5414d0c), [Gandhi](https://open.spotify.com/episode/6e0lQp7P1s7tJ2wQ0JESBe?si=2297f9a73d024b81)[^3], [Jinnah](https://open.spotify.com/episode/4oT2ew1YbE8IemZeI8mEr1?si=fcae51bebae94426) (Founding Father of Pakistan), [Mountbatten](https://open.spotify.com/episode/1jMCP4BpfSzkfQtiyETEt6?si=4a42ee2acf074fe4) (Last Viceroy of India), and [Partition of India and birth of Pakistan](https://open.spotify.com/episode/51M9szI5FjBXGyUgAh4BMZ?si=3f44047aef0644df).

[^3]: On a sidenote, I've never respected anyone more than Mahatma Gandhi.
    No one has valued truth and the personal search for it through experiments like him.
    No one before him, and no one since him.

[^4]: Someone says "all translations are opinionated".
